raw: * A finite state machine.

raw: * The name of this finite state machine (for debug messages)

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The name of this finite state machine (for debug messages)

raw: * The current state of the finite state machine.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The current state of the finite state machine.

raw: * The previous state of the finite state machine, i.e. the state from
* which we most recently transitioned.  Note that this could be the same
* as the current state if a successful transition brought us back to the
* same state.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The previous state of the finite state machine, i.e. the state from which we most recently transitioned. Note that this could be the same as the current state if a successful transition brought us back to the same state.

raw: * The state to which we will be transitioning.  This property is valid
* only during a Transition's ontransition function and a State's onexit
* function.  At all other times, it is null.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The state to which we will be transitioning. This property is valid only during a Transition's ontransition function and a State's onexit function. At all other times, it is null.

raw: * The maximum number of states which may pushed onto the state-stack.  It
* is generally a poor idea to have very many states saved on a stack.
* Following program logic becomes very difficult, and the code can be
* highly unmaintainable.  The default should be more than adequate.
* You've been warned.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The maximum number of states which may pushed onto the state-stack. It is generally a poor idea to have very many states saved on a stack. Following program logic becomes very difficult, and the code can be highly unmaintainable. The default should be more than adequate. You've been warned.

raw: * Debug flags, composed of the bitmask values in the DebugFlags constant.
* Set the debug flags from the application by or-ing together bits, akin
* to this:
* <pre class='javascript'>
* var FSM = qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine;
* fsm.setDebugFlags(FSM.DebugFlags.EVENTS |
*                   FSM.DebugFlags.TRANSITIONS |
*                   FSM.DebugFlags.FUNCTION_DETAIL |
*                   FSM.DebugFlags.OBJECT_NOT_FOUND);
*

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Debug flags, composed of the bitmask values in the DebugFlags constant. Set the debug flags from the application by or-ing together bits, akin to this: 

 var FSM = qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine;
 fsm.setDebugFlags(FSM.DebugFlags.EVENTS |
                   FSM.DebugFlags.TRANSITIONS |
                   FSM.DebugFlags.FUNCTION_DETAIL |
                   FSM.DebugFlags.OBJECT_NOT_FOUND);

raw: * Checks whether the finite state machine is terminated or not.

@return.body: {Boolean} If the finite state machine is terminated.
@return.description: If the finite state machine is terminated.

raw: * Add a state to the finite state machine.
* @param state {qx.util.fsm.State}
*   An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to
*   be a part of this finite state machine.
* @throws {Error} If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.
* @throws {Error} If the given state already exists.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Add a state to the finite state machine.

@param.name: @param
@param.description:
An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to
   be a part of this finite state machine.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.
@throws.description: If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the given state already exists.
@throws.description: If the given state already exists.

raw: * Replace a state in the finite state machine.  This is useful if
* initially "dummy" states are created which load the real state table
* for a series of operations (and possibly also load the gui associated
* with the new states at the same time).  Having portions of the finite
* state machine and their associated gui pages loaded at run time can
* help prevent long delays at application start-up time.
* @param state {qx.util.fsm.State}
*   An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to
*   be a part of this finite state machine.
* @param bDispose {Boolean}
* If true, then dispose the old state object. If false,
*   the old state object is returned for disposing by the caller.
* @return {Object}
*   The old state object if it was not disposed; otherwise null.
* @throws {Error} If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Replace a state in the finite state machine. This is useful if initially "dummy" states are created which load the real state table for a series of operations (and possibly also load the gui associated with the new states at the same time). Having portions of the finite state machine and their associated gui pages loaded at run time can help prevent long delays at application start-up time.

@param.name: @param
@param.description:
An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to
   be a part of this finite state machine.

@param.name: @param
@param.description: If true, then dispose the old state object. If false, the old state object is returned for disposing by the caller.

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{Object}
   The old state object if it was not disposed; otherwise null.
@return.description: The old state object if it was not disposed; otherwise null.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.
@throws.description: If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.

@param.body:
obj {Object}
   The object to associate with the specified friendly name

@param.name: @param

groupNames {Array}
   An optional list of group names of which this object is a member.
@param.description: An optional list of group names of which this object is a member.

The friendly name associated with an object, specifying which object

raw: * Get internal data for debugging

*     __states
*     __startState
*     __eventQueue
*     __blockedEvents
*     __savedStates
*     __friendlyToObject
*     __friendlyToHash
*     __hashToFriendly
*     __groupToFriendly
*     __friendlyToGroups
*     __bEventProcessingInProgress

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Get internal data for debugging

raw: * Start (or restart, after it has terminated) the finite state machine
* from the starting state.  The starting state is defined as the first
* state added to the finite state machine.
* @throws {Error} If the machine stared with not available state.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Start (or restart, after it has terminated) the finite state machine from the starting state. The starting state is defined as the first state added to the finite state machine.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the machine stared with not available state.
@throws.description: If the machine stared with not available state.

raw: * Save the current or previous state on the saved-state stack.  A future
* transition can then provide, as its nextState value, the class
* constant:
*   <code>
*   qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine.StateChange.POP_STATE_STACK
*
* which will cause the next state to be whatever is at the top of the
* saved-state stack, and remove that top element from the saved-state
* stack.
* @param state {Boolean|String}
* When true, then push the current state onto the stack. This
*   might be used in a transition, before the state has changed.  When
* false, then push the previous state onto the stack. This
*   might be used in an on entry function to save the previous state to
*   return to.  If this parameter is a string, it is taken to be the
*   name of the state to transition to.
* @throws {Error} If the saved-state stack is full.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Save the current or previous state on the saved-state stack. A future transition can then provide, as its nextState value, the class constant: qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine.StateChange.POP_STATE_STACK which will cause the next state to be whatever is at the top of the saved-state stack, and remove that top element from the saved-state stack.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: state {Boolean|String} When true, then push the current state onto the stack. This might be used in a transition, before the state has changed. When false, then push the previous state onto the stack. This might be used in an on entry function to save the previous state to return to. If this parameter is a string, it is taken to be the name of the state to transition to.
@param.description: When true, then push the current state onto the stack. This might be used in a transition, before the state has changed. When false, then push the previous state onto the stack. This might be used in an on entry function to save the previous state to return to. If this parameter is a string, it is taken to be the name of the state to transition to.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the saved-state stack is full.
@throws.description: If the saved-state stack is full.

raw: * Pop the saved state stack.
* @return {String|Boolean}
*   The name of a state or a boolean flag that had most recently been
*   pushed onto the saved-state stack.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Pop the saved state stack.

@return.name: @return
@return.description:
The name of a state or a boolean flag that had most recently been
   pushed onto the saved-state stack.

raw: * Add the specified event to a list of events to be passed to the next
* state following state transition.

@description.body: Add the specified event to a list of events to be passed to the next state following state transition.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
event {qx.event.type.Event}
   The event to add to the event queue for processing after state change.
@param.description: The event to add to the event queue for processing after state change.

raw: * Enqueue an event for processing
* @param event {qx.event.type.Event}
*   The event to be enqueued
* @param bAddAtHead {Boolean}
* If true, put the event at the head of the queue for immediate
* processing. If false, place the event at the tail of the
*   queue so that it receives in-order processing.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Enqueue an event for processing

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
event {qx.event.type.Event}
   The event to be enqueued
@param.description: The event to be enqueued

@param.name: @param
@param.body: bAddAtHead {Boolean} If true, put the event at the head of the queue for immediate processing. If false, place the event at the tail of the queue so that it receives in-order processing.
@param.description: If true, put the event at the head of the queue for immediate processing. If false, place the event at the tail of the queue so that it receives in-order processing.

raw: * Event listener for all event types in the finite state machine
* @param event {qx.event.type.Event} The event that was dispatched.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Event listener for all event types in the finite state machine

@param.name: @param
@param.body: event {qx.event.type.Event} The event that was dispatched.
@param.description: The event that was dispatched.

raw: * Create an event and send it immediately to the finite state machine.
* @param type {String}
*   The type of event, e.g. "execute"
* @param target {qx.core.Object}
*   The target of the event
* @param data {Object|null}
*   The data, if any, to issue in the event.  If this parameter is null
*   then a qx.event.type.Event is instantiated.  Otherwise, an event of
*   type qx.event.type.Data is instantiated and this data is applied to
*   it.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Create an event and send it immediately to the finite state machine.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
type {String}
   The type of event, e.g. "execute"
@param.description: The type of event, e.g. "execute"

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
target {qx.core.Object}
   The target of the event
@param.description: The target of the event

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
data {Object|null}
   The data, if any, to issue in the event.  If this parameter is null
   then a qx.event.type.Event is instantiated.  Otherwise, an event of
   type qx.event.type.Data is instantiated and this data is applied to
   it.
@param.description:
The data, if any, to issue in the event.  If this parameter is null
   then a qx.event.type.Event is instantiated.  Otherwise, an event of
   type qx.event.type.Data is instantiated and this data is applied to
   it.

raw: * Create and schedule an event to be sent to the finite state machine
* "shortly".  This allows such things as letting a progress cursor
* display prior to handling the event.
* @param type {String}
*   The type of event, e.g. "execute"
* @param target {qx.core.Object}
*   The target of the event
* @param data {Object|null}
*   See {@link #fireImmediateEvent} for details.
* @param timeout {Integer|null}
*   If provided, this is the number of milliseconds to wait before firing
*   the event.  If not provided, a default short interval (on the order
*   of 20 milliseconds) is used.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Create and schedule an event to be sent to the finite state machine "shortly". This allows such things as letting a progress cursor display prior to handling the event.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
type {String}
   The type of event, e.g. "execute"
@param.description: The type of event, e.g. "execute"

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
target {qx.core.Object}
   The target of the event
@param.description: The target of the event

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
data {Object|null}
   See {@link #fireImmediateEvent} for details.
@param.description: See {@link #fireImmediateEvent} for details.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
timeout {Integer|null}
   If provided, this is the number of milliseconds to wait before firing
   the event.  If not provided, a default short interval (on the order
   of 20 milliseconds) is used.
@param.description:
If provided, this is the number of milliseconds to wait before firing
   the event.  If not provided, a default short interval (on the order
   of 20 milliseconds) is used.

raw: * Process all of the events on the event queue.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Process all of the events on the event queue.

raw: * Run the finite state machine to process a single event.
* @param event {qx.event.type.Event}
*   An event that has been dispatched.  The event may be handled (if the
*   current state handles this event type), queued (if the current state
*   blocks this event type), or discarded (if the current state neither
*   handles nor blocks this event type).
* @return {Boolean}
*   Whether the event should be disposed.  If it was blocked, we've
*   pushed it back onto the event queue, and it should not be disposed.
* @throws {Error} If the explicit transitions does not exist.
* @throws {Error} If the transition returns an invalid value.
* @throws {Error} If the next step will transit to an nonexistent state.
* @throws {Error} If the state stack is empty and the next state is POP_STATE_STACK
* @throws {Error} If the next state is invalid.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Run the finite state machine to process a single event.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
event {qx.event.type.Event}
   An event that has been dispatched.  The event may be handled (if the
   current state handles this event type), queued (if the current state
   blocks this event type), or discarded (if the current state neither
   handles nor blocks this event type).
@param.description:
An event that has been dispatched.  The event may be handled (if the
   current state handles this event type), queued (if the current state
   blocks this event type), or discarded (if the current state neither
   handles nor blocks this event type).

@return.name: @return
@return.description:
Whether the event should be disposed.  If it was blocked, we've
   pushed it back onto the event queue, and it should not be disposed.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the explicit transitions does not exist.
@throws.description: If the explicit transitions does not exist.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the transition returns an invalid value.
@throws.description: If the transition returns an invalid value.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the next step will transit to an nonexistent state.
@throws.description: If the next step will transit to an nonexistent state.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the state stack is empty and the next state is POP_STATE_STACK
@throws.description: If the state stack is empty and the next state is POP_STATE_STACK

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the next state is invalid.
@throws.description: If the next state is invalid.
